_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]
Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The ConocoPhillips Ferndale Refinery is located in Ferndale, Washington, in Whatcom County.  It receives crude oil, which it processes into petroleum products, including gasoline, transportation fuels, LPG, and oils.  In addition to the flammable materials associated with crude oil processing, the facility uses hydrofluoric acid in the Alkylation Unit, which is a standard refining application.  The processing of the crude oil results in the generation of hydrogen sulfide. Sulfur Recovery Units process the hydrogen sulfide and sulfur dioxide to recover sulfur for sale and to limit SO2 and CO2 emissions to atmosphere at quantities below the allowable limits.  Hydrogen Sulfide and other toxic chemicals, such as ammonia hydrochloric acid, and sulfur dioxide are present in quantities far below the regulated threshold amounts.  

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The federal Risk Management Program requires ConocoPhillips Company, Ferndale Refinery (ConocoPhillips) to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for any processes containing regulated substances above threshold quantity (TQ) at the Ferndale Refinery.  The Ferndale Refinery handles hazardous materials onsite, and recognizes a responsibility to safely operate the facility in order to protect the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.  The facility has taken a proactive stance to promote the overall safe operation of the processes, with programs to prevent accidents from occurring, planning for emergencies, and maintaining the equipment needed if an emergency does occur.  The RMP formalizes existing programs and procedures so that these programs may be reviewed more efficiently.

The Ferndale Refinery processes oil into gasoline and refining products.  The facility receives oil from many sources via ship or pipeline, stores it in tanks onsite, and then processes the oil into products to be shipped elsewhere by pipeline, railcar, barge or truck.  The refining process separates the crude oil into fi

ve products: gasoline, diesel fuel, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), heavy fuel oil and sulfur.  The sulfur is generated because oil contains significant quantities of sulfur that must be removed to produce clean burning gasoline and diesel.  The fuel products are also stored in onsite storage prior to shipping, and any non-hydrocarbon products e.g. sulfur is also stored prior to shipping.  The facility also has the utility and support systems required providing for safe operation of the facility.

The RMP contains two parts required for submittal:

* RMP Executive Summary, Prevention Program Summary, and Management System Summary
* RMP Data Elements

The original 1999 RMP effort at the facility was divided into three phases.  First, the facility determined which processes were covered by the RMP regulation.  The results of this study are published in the report titled "Phase I: Inventory Determination" which measured the quantities of regulated substances to determine which processes are subject to RMP.  Next, the facility conducted the required hazard assessment as defined by the regulation.  The hazard assessment modeled accidental release scenarios that provided the refinery with insight into the potential for onsite processes to affect the surrounding community and the environment.   Finally, Phase III of the RMP effort is provided in this document.  It contains the executive summary of the overall RMP effort at the facility, a synopsis of the prevention program, a five-year accident history and summary of the management systems in place to implement and maintain the facility's risk management measures.

The following changes have been made to the RMP submission documents as part of the June, 2009 Update: 

* Divided covered refinery processes into separate processing units,
* Revised hydrofluoric acid Toxic Worst Case Release Scenario to reflect current operations,
* Added stored LPG railcar inventories,
* Added another railcar Flammable Alternative Release Scen

ario

The executive summary and data elements are submitted to Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the federal government as part of its Risk Management Plan.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS 
The objectives of this hazard assessment are twofold: (1) satisfy the requirements of the RMP regulation and (2) provide Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) information that will help local emergency planning officials improve community emergency response in the event of an accidental release at the refinery.

For all covered process units, the facility has submitted to the EPA a worst case and alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held in the covered process, and worst case and alternative release scenarios for flammable substances in covered process units.

The EPA has provided the levels of concern (LOC) for certain regulated substances that have the potential to be carried offsite during a release.  For regulated substances where emergency response planning guidelines (ERPG) values have been established, RMP requires that the ERPG-2 value be used as the toxic endpoint.  RMP also requires an offsite consequence analysis for potential releases of flammable materials.  In modeling flammable materials, the stationary source is required to present distances to endpoints resulting from any of the following:

* Explosion: Overpressure of 1 psig.
* Radiant Heat/Fire: Radiant heat of 5 kW/m2 for 40 seconds.
* Lower Flammability Limit: a lower flammability limit as provided in NFPA documents or other generally recognized sources.

In addition, the facility has modeled alternative release scenarios (ARSs), to show release scenarios that may have more realistic chance of occurrence.  The alternative release scenarios allow the facility to present scenarios that assume the use of administrative and actual controls in place at the facility. Even the ARSs are rare events.  The details of the process release conditions assumed for this and other hazard scenari

os, and assumptions made, are provided in the Phase II hazard assessment report and the 2009 RMP Update Report.  Both are available at the facility.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The RMP rule requires facilities to compile a 5-Year Accident History for all RMP regulated substances in covered processes at the facility.  As part of the ongoing PSM Program, the facility documents and tracks all incidents and near-misses that occur within the facility.  This incident database serves as the basis for the five-year accident history.

RMP requires facilities to report any incident from a covered process involving a regulated substance and resulting in any of the following:

* Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage
* Offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or environmental damage

The Facility has had no such accidents in the preceding 5 years.  This is a strong indication of the successful risk management program in practice at the facility.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the refinery.  Because processes at the facility that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.  Each section below contains a brief summary of the prevention program elements.  Each summary also designates the responsible party for each element.

PP1. Employee Participation: 
The intent of this element is to involve employees in the development and implementation of the various PSM element compliance activities.  This involvement is intended to be a cooperative, interactive effort that will bring together the best resources at the refinery to achieve a sound loss prevention program.  Employee Participation is the responsibility of the PSM Lead.

The refinery Health & Safety Committee is the primary for

um for discussing and assuring employee participation with the individual elements of the PSM standard.  Employees are involved in all the PSM elements, as described below:

Process Safety Information (PSI): Employees knowledgeable in the specific process are asked to assist in the upkeep of PSI to ensure current and thorough documentation of the equipment and safety systems at the refinery.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): All process hazard analysis studies require that an employee knowledgeable in the specific process be a member of the study team.  All affected employees have access to documentation reports for the PHA.

Operating Procedures: Employees knowledgeable in specific processes are asked to develop and review operating procedures to ensure that the operating procedures are current and thorough.  

Training:  The Joint Operations Training Steering Committee and the Maintenance Training Steering Committee are responsible for recommending specific types and forms of training.  Composition of the committee requires employee representation from various appropriate groups within the refinery organization.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews: PSSRs are completed through the Management of Change Process. In addition to MOC, Project Engineering completes a Process Safety Review (PSR) as a compliment to PSSR.  Employees knowledgeable in the process participate in all applicable stages of the PSR process.  All affected employees have access to documentation reports for the PSR.

Mechanical Integrity: A team that includes individuals with appropriate expertise address aspects of the mechanical integrity provisions of the PSM standard.  

Incident Investigation: This facility includes employee representatives when conducting of any formal incident investigations.  

Modification or conduct of the remaining elements of the PSM standard will be reviewed and reported to the refinery Joint Health & Safety Committee, which is comprised of employees in various positions throughou

t the refinery.

PP2. Process Safety Information (PSI)
The refinery provides complete and accurate information concerning all covered processes.  This information is essential for having an effective process safety management program and for conducting thorough process hazards analysis.  This includes information regarding process chemicals, process technology and process equipment.  The Process and Project Leads are responsible for the refinery PSI.

PP3. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each refinery processing unit is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. The PSM Lead is responsible for the PHA program.

The ConocoPhillips risk matrix is used to qualitatively assign risk to each hazard scenario based on the potential severity and likelihood, given existing control measures.  Any recommendations needed to mitigate a hazardous consequence made in the PHA study receive a priority ranking. Those mitigation recommendations with the highest priority (most severe risk) are handled first. All mitigation recommendations receive a thorough evaluation in a timely manner.  Other risk management tools, such as Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA), and a Safety Integrity Level (SIL) evaluation, are also used to ensure the reliability of safety systems.

The facility continues to redefine the baseline and revalidate the PHA studies for the processing units on an alternating 5 year schedule, or sooner as changes to the process require.  All new changes to the refinery, including new refinery units, are evalua

ted using a PHA with ample time for recommendation implementation prior to the startup of the unit or change.  All PHA studies are retained and may be reviewed by employees.

PP4. Operating Procedures
The facility develops and implements written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities in each processing unit.  The tasks and procedures are appropriate, clear, consistent, and communicated with the employees.  This program is designed to satisfy the PSM regulation, RMP requirements, and meet all parts of the compliance guidelines in CPL 2-2.45A, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals-- Compliance Guidelines and Enforcement Procedures.  Operating procedures are the responsibility of the Operations Manager and the Business Team Leads.

Operating procedures address all applicable modes of operation, including startup, shutdown, normal operation, emergency shutdown, as well as temporary or batch procedures, as needed.  Knowledgeable employees periodically review operating procedures to ensure that they are current and accurate.  Any changes to procedures are communicated to the affected employees.

PP5. Training
The intent of the facility training program is to ensure that the products processed in this facility are handled in a consistent and safe manner.  This is accomplished by having well trained employees.  An effective training program will help unit operators, maintenance personnel, and technicians to understand the nature and causes of problems arising from the process operations and will increase the employee's awareness with respect to the hazards of a particular process thereby preventing unplanned catastrophic incidents. Training is the responsibility of the Process Safety Education Director.

All affected employees are trained on changes to the facility, including the startup of new refinery units, and receive refresher training to ensure that all required skills and knowledge are current.  

PP6.

Contractors
It is the refinery philosophy that all injuries are preventable.  This applies to all personnel on the Ferndale site whether they are ConocoPhillips employees or contract employees.  Contract employees are used throughout the refinery, especially in times of construction, turn-around, or startup, and they are required to adhere to the same safety standards as ConocoPhillips employees. This policy is intended to help assure the refinery that its contractors and subcontractors are qualified and have an effective safety process that meets the requirements of the refinery. Contractors are the responsibility of the Maintenance Manager.

PP7. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
The purpose of the Pre-Startup Safety Review procedure is to ensure that a new unit, or a modification to an existing unit is ready to operate safely.  This is a final check to ensure that all important considerations have been taken into account before a highly hazardous chemical is introduced to the process.  This includes a check to ensure that all portions of the Management of Change program have been followed, including the conduct of a PHA, update to the Process Safety Information, training of employees, and development of operating procedures and emergency response procedures.  It also provides field verification that the equipment is constructed and installed as designed.   Each Area Business Team Leader (BTL) or delegate is responsible for the PSSR.

PP8. Mechanical Integrity
The objective of the Mechanical Integrity Program is to assure that equipment used to process, store or handle hazardous chemicals is designed, constructed, installed, inspected, and maintained per good engineering practices.  This will minimize the risk of releases of such chemicals.  The facility has programs for:

* Fire protection equipment
* Control and instrumentation systems
* Pumps and compressors
* Furnaces
* Piping systems
* Valves
* Tanks and storage vessels
* Pressure vessels, heat exchangers, a

nd boilers

Responsibilities for the components of this Program are as follows:

* Inspection/Testing Procedures: Inspection Supervisor
* Repair Procedures: Inspection Supervisor
* Engineering Procedures: Project Engineering Superintendent and Technical Services Manager
* Training Documentation: Training Superintendent
* Repair Execution: Maintenance Supervisors and Contract Coordinators
* Preventive Maintenance: See Mechanical Integrity Programs for PSVs and Controls

The ANSI/ISA S84.01 Safety Instrumented Systems guidance has been adopted by the facility, and is used for all new installations of safety instrumented systems and equipment, for reliability purposes.

The facility uses input from multiple sources, including the PHA studies, to determine which equipment is integral to the safety of the facility, and provides critical maintenance and reliability checks accordingly.

PP9. Safe Work Practices
The refinery provides a safe and healthful work place for the workers at the facility, contractors, visitors, and the community surrounding the facility.  Safe work practices are in place to ensure that common hazardous activities are conducted safely.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel and contractors, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.  Safe work practices are the responsibility of the HSE Manager. 
Examples of standard safe work practices at the refinery include: 

* Tracking and control of the entry/presence/exit of personnel into and out of the facility 
* A control of hazardous energy procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance (lock-out/tag-out)
* A procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened
* A permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work)
* A permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined

space
* In addition to the safe work practices outlined above, the refinery conducts regular physical conditions inspections to ensure compliance with federal, state, and local regulations, and company loss control requirements.

Specific physical conditions inspections are conducted of each processing unit, storage and tankage areas, maintenance facilities, warehouse, laboratory, office buildings, and contractor work sites.  Safe work practices, such as lock out/ tag out, hot work, etc. are available from the safe work practices database.

PP10.    Management of Change
The intent of this procedure is to assume that all modifications to equipment, raw materials and processing condition other than "replacement in kind" are safe.  This includes a review of applicable changes using the appropriate PHA method (Checklist, What-If, HAZOP, etc.), and ensuring that all prevention programs are included in the change.  Management of Changes is the responsibility of the PSM Lead, and encompasses all prevention programs.

PP11. Incident Investigation
The incident investigation program covers all loss and near loss (near-miss) incidents that occur at the refinery.  Examples of incidents covered by this policy but not limited to are: occupational injuries and illness, unit upsets, production loss, property damage or loss, and environmental incidents such as spills and releases.  Incident investigation is the responsibility of the HSE Manager.

The purpose of this guideline is to ensure that effective incident reporting and investigation procedures are carried out efficiently.  To be effective, all investigations are conducted in a timely, organized and objective manner.  The purpose of an investigation is not to fix blame, but rather to determine the facts surrounding the incident, present the findings and conclusions, and make recommendations for corrective actions that will prevent a similar occurrence in the future.  An incident investigation team will investigate all incidents a

s defined in Section 68.60 of the RMP Guidance.

All near-misses and incidents are reviewed during the 5-year revalidation of the unit PHA studies, to provide the PHA team with insight into actual hazards that may occur.

PP12.    Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Ferndale Refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.

Per WAC 296-67-057, this facility verifies PSM compliance every three years with an audit.  The refinery will retain the two most recent compliance audit reports for inspection. The PSM Lead is responsible for implementing the compliance audit portion of the prevention program.

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the Program level 3 refining processes at the Facility.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Some of the administrative programs to prevent, detect or mitigate an incident at the facility are presented above.  Specific safety equipment and procedures, known as safeguards, are in place at the facility.  These safeguards are listed as part of the process hazard analyses, process safety information, and in the operating procedures.  Some examples of general safeguards are presented below:

Release Detection
* Hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen fluoride detectors with alarms
* Facility alarm system to notify personnel in case of emergency
* Ambient SO2 Monitoring Station

Release Containment/Control
* Pressure Safety Valves (PSVs) to protect all pressure vessels
* Operating materials recovery system with process flare to incinerate excess materials from the process
* Manual and automatic valves to pe

rmit isolation of the process
* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters
* Excess flow valves that prevent product loss if a loading line should fail. 
* "Fail-Safe" valves to isolate equipment in case of unplanned events such as power failures and earthquakes
* Containment around all tanks and process areas to contain liquid materials
* Backup power supply for critical process equipment
* Tank vapor recovery system to contain hazardous tank vapors

Release Mitigation
* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
* Deluge system for specific equipment
* Trained emergency response personnel
* Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
* Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel
* Backup fire protection equipment

Other specific safeguards include:
* Acid Inventory Management System (AIMS) for the hydrofluoric acid in the Alkylation Unit, which minimizes the potential release in the case of a leak or damage to equipment.
* Perimeter monitors for hydrofluoric acid allow for rapid detection and response in the unlikely event of a leak of hydrofluoric acid from the Alkylation Unit.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The refinery provides resources for planning in case of emergencies at the facility.  The Facility is a contributor to the community by protecting the plant and neighbors from damaging effects of emergency situations.  The facility design, maintenance, operating procedures, and training provide for risk minimization before an accident can occur.  In spite of all these things, emergencies can arise, sometimes through forces beyond control.  The emergency response plan known as the Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP), along with training and drills, is designed to prepare the facility to recognize emergency situations of various types and react promptly and correctly to minimize any ill effects.  Local, state, and federal safety rules dictate the facility to study and under

stand the principles and specifics covered in this preplanning effort and fully understand all roles in the plan.

The purpose of this emergency plan (ICP) is to provide a cohesive, written procedure for coordinating effective response procedures by all plant personnel in order that danger to employees, contractors, the general public and the environment may be lessened in the unlikely event of an emergency.  The emergency response procedure covers the entire facility, including refinery units that handle or produce regulated substances.  It includes, but is not limited to: first-in response, evacuation, emergency shutdown, decontamination and medical response to chemical exposure, agency notification, public notification if potential for impact, personnel accounting, and clean-up.

Training for emergency response is handled through the Process Safety Education Department, and is conducted frequently with classroom, tabletop, and live exercises.  As the facility continues to expand, the Emergency Response Plan (ICP) is updated to include the new refinery units and changes to operations. 

MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
The Refinery Manager is ultimately responsible for implementation of the risk management measures set forth in this document.  The Process Safety Management Lead is responsible for upkeep of the Risk Management Plan and Hazard Assessment, and all supporting documentation.  The individual departments assigned above implement each element of the Prevention Program.

ENHANCEMENTS TO SAFETY
Through the use of prevention programs such as Management of Change and the Process Hazard Analysis program, ConocoPhillips is constantly re-evaluating the current safety systems. As a result of these programs, and other safety and risk reduction initiatives, improvements to the safety of the workers and the surrounding community continue to occur. All hazardous consequence mitigation recommendations from PHAs relating to safety and environment are prioritized by a risk matrix des

igned to address highest risk scenarios first. All hazardous consequence mitigation recommendations are resolved in a timely manner.

The following is an example of the types of modifications made to the facility during the period from 1999 to 2009:

1. HF Laser Detectors installed in the acid section of the Alkylation Unit.  These provide a quick detection of a hydrofluoric acid release, and allow operators and the emergency response team to respond accordingly.

2. Acid Inventory Management System implemented in the acid section of the Alkylation Unit, which allows operators to transfer hydrofluoric acid from process unit equipment to a single safe storage location. If a leak were to occur within the process equipment, the operator can activate the emergency acid inventory management systems (AIMS) to reduce the duration of an acid release, and to store the acid in a safe location until the equipment can be repaired.  When the system has been repaired, the acid in the emergency system can be safely transferred back into the process, without requiring any disposal of material.

3. As a result of the Y2K Task Force, the facility experienced no upsets, environmental impacts and no safety concerns as a result of the potential Year 2000 data change problems in electrical equipment.  The changes made to the facility and programs put in place as a result of the Y2K Task Force improve the reliability of the facility's safety systems in the unlikely event of future troubles with power supply, field instrumentation, or other electrical control systems.

4. The facility security has been improved to control access to the refinery process units with the use of card-access and turnstile gates and vehicle gates, to lessen the potential for unauthorized access. 

5. The Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC) program has been implemented at this facility. 

The following future projects will be implemented to enhance safety:

1. LPG Monitoring

2. Atmospheric PSV

to Flare

3. Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS)

4. Emergency Isolation Valves (EIV)
